title: If nothing exists, does nothing exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question is quite tricky. It says “If nothing exists, does nothing exist?” Logically, the answer would be yes, but it is a qualified yes, an affirmation based simply on the given assumption, supposition, if. In short “if x, therefore x” where x= “nothing”. But if we remove the assumption, the hypothetical supposition, and simply ask “Does nothing exist?”, then the answer needs another premise, a premise other than the assumption that it exists. For us to be able to answer the question, we have to define or have a more or less common understanding of what nothing and what existence mean. Hence, the answers would depend on the definitions of what these two terms mean. (Actually we may also need to define or have a more or less common understanding of what do means, for in its declarative form the sentence would not only be “Nothing exists,” but could also be “Nothing does exist” or it can even be “There is nothing which does the [act of] existing.”) Anyway, I read some answers here, which I find confusing or confused. Big Bang Theory (at least the present so-called standard model) does not assert that everything came out of nothing. What it states is that the present notion of space and time must have begun around 13.6 million years ago, beyond which the current understanding of science is not yet able to explain (FYI: I am not a ‘fan’ of BBT, I am just trying to clarify.)Zero is not necessarily nothing. For instance, it is a specific point in the number line from which positive numbers follow to the right and negative numbers to rhe left. Zero degree celsius is not the absence of temperature nor of the Celsius measuring unit, it is in fact a specific amount of temperature or a specific point in the thermometer at which liquid water turns to ice.In philosophy, i.e., in materialism, matter is the substance of all things, which includes the non-matter physical entities in physics. Meanwhile energy can be construed as a property of matter.In physics, “nothing comes out of nothing” is but an expression of a law of thermodynamics, the conservation of mass and energy.Now, I know I have not answered the question, but I hope this helps.

I choose to see this as a playful question of the mind, and one that points to the limitation of language as we usually think of it. It is not a question of the heart. Take the expression “Nothing is the matter.” It is like saying “Matter is nothing.” In the language of physics we see matter as a form of energy vibrating at a certain frequency: “not a thing.” So now we have an unconventional sense of the familiar expression, “Nothing’s the matter.” Matter is energy. Looking at “nothing” as equivalent to “energy” allows us to rephrase the original question in this way: “If energy exists, does energy exist?” Now it is clearly an oxymoron. To which we can reply: “The answer is there is no question.” I like this answer when it comes to matters of the heart. Life is a mystery to be embraced and enjoyed. Questions have their place, but not on the deepest levels of “existence” where we need to learn the language of love that swells within the human heart. It depends on what you mean. If you mean “nothing” as an abstract concept, then yes, I would say that it exists. There is a concrete definition of “nothing” and I can use it in context just like any other word. If, however, you mean it as a tangible thing, it gets a bit more complicated. Space, for example, is in essence nothing. It is an empty, dark, cold vacuum. So, in one sense it does exist, because space is a very real fact in our universe, but at the same time, it doesn't exist, because it is defined as the absence of “things”. In the end, however, it’s up to you, to make your own conclusion.

When you analyse existence deeply it can be proved that existence always refers to something real or imaginary. Either something real exists or something imaginary and unreal exists. As such nothing exists is itself a fallacy. It can neither be correct nor true to say that nothing exists. If you insist that nothing exists it can be logically proved that you are wrong because there is your mind imagining that nothing exists and when your mind is present it is wrong to say that nothing exists. As the question is illogical there is no answer possible. However when you consider a closed system like a vacuum tube, it is true that nothing exists in a vacuum. It only means that matter does not exist in the vacuum. If we replace the word 'nothing' by 'no matter' it will be right to say that if no matter exists, then no matter exists.

Let’s start here. Thingness = the essence of existence Therefore, nothingness = the essence of non-existence Nothing does not exist, because if it existed, it would be a thing (and things are not no-thing). So nothing does not exist, however, it does subsist. Subsistence is just a broader category than existence. It’s a category that includes both existence and non-existence as well as any other concept for any other type of “…-existence.”
